title: Beware wet paint / designs by Alan Fletcher
notes: Lovely work, and a timely book to rekindle my interest in design and illustration. Feel like I've lost my mojo somewhat, and enjoying great work like this is really helpful.

title: Concrete
notes: One person's collection of interesting concrete structures, couldn't see much organisation beyond that.

title: A Mindfulness Guide for the Frazzled
notes: An entertaing, no shit guide to taking care of your mind.

title: Sapiens
notes: I keep (probably erroneously) summarising some of the key points from this book in discussions about lots of things. Probably a good sign. Really interesting, big ideas explained in a way that a dummy like me can understand.

title: Playing to the Gallery: Helping Contemporary Art in its Struggle to Be Understood
notes: Like his lecturers and interviews, great fun. Also very clear and direct - words not usually associated with contemporary art. And small enough to be a frequent re-read.

title: Moneyball
notes: Great fun - loved how it related the data and stats to the real life characters.

title: Forms That Work : Designing Web Forms for Usability
notes: Read it very quickly - loved it. Will keep dipping in and out.

title: The End of the Affair
notes: Took a little while for me to get into it, and was made easier when the plot moved along a little.  Looked for a while like it was going to be a simple mystery about who was doing what, but got more into the relationships and internal struggles of the protagonists. WHich was more satisfying than that sounds.

title: The Biggest Game in Town
notes: Entertaining trawl through the world of Poker - which I suspect has changed quite a bit since it was written.

title: Never use futura
notes: Lovely examination, exploration and eplanation of a typeface. Great journey through how it was made, why it was made, how it was and is used and a myriad of cultural touchpoints in between. All clearly and engagingly written, with good illustrations. Also worth mentioning that it comes as a nicely portable pleasure object.

title: Raw Concrete: The Beauty of Brutalism
notes:
Recommending to everyone I know. Such a meaty, interesting book. Nominally the author's personal tour of Brutalist arhcitecture it folds in so many interesting and intruiging things alongside his personal response to the features buildings. Placing the Brutalist examples in their own contexts makes for a great understanding of how these, and all buildings come about against cultural, economic and social backgrounds. He also manages to throw in some great insight into the personalities and processes involved in the creation of these great projects.
Really rekindled my dormat interest in Architecture, and allied with great footnotes, has set me on the path to read more.

title: How Not To Be a Boy
notes: Funny, and at times ponder worthy memoirs.

title: How to Read a Building (Collins Need to Know?)
notes: Good run through architectural history with plenty of suggested jump off points to other books.

title: The Old Ways: A Journey on Foot
notes: A bit like some of the walks in the book, I found some of it tough going. A bit dense with the descriptions of landscapes and the things in it, even though it made me look things up, which is no bad thing. Enjoyed it more when it became more speculative, and was thankful of the discovery of the artist, Eric Ravilious. That bit of the book was great.

title: How I won the Yellow Jumper
notes: Easy read, pleasant enough. Sort of fast food of a book.

title: Hawksmoor
notes: Fascinating. Thought it was going to be more plotty, turned out not so much.

title: How we got to now
notes: Rather enjoyable - I must have bored quite a few people with half-remembered snippets from various parts of this. Generally fascintating and very accessible.
